msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Exodus 12
ab.l:
And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron
in the land of Egypt, saying,

‘This month
is the beginning of months to you. It is the first
month of the year for you.

Speak to all the congregation
of Israel, saying, “In the tenth day of this month
they shall take to them every man a sheep, according to the house of their fathers,
a sheep for a house.

And if the people of the house be fewer
than those who would eat the sheep, then he
and his neighbour that is close to his house shall take according to the number of souls,
according to every person’s eating you shall appoint yourself for the lamb.

Your sheep shall be unblemished male, a one-year-old young;
you shall take it from the sheep or from the goats.

And you shall keep it until the fourteenth day
of the same month. And the whole assembly of the congregation of
Israel shall slaughter it at twilight.

And
they shall take of the blood, and put it on the two side posts
and on the upper door post,
on the houses in which they shall eat it.

And they shall eat the flesh in this night, they shall eat it roasted in fire
with unleavened bread |on| bitter herbs.

Do not eat
jaḥny or boiled in water,
but roasted in fire: its head with its knees, and with the entrails.
(10) And you shall let nothing of it remain until the morning, and that which remains of it
until the morning you shall burn in fire.

And thus shall you eat
it: your hips shall be girded, your shoes shall be
on your feet, and your staff in your hand; and you shall eat it
in haste. It is the Lord’s Passover.

And my command will pass through the land of Egypt this night,
and will slay all the firstborn in the land of Egypt,
both man and beast, and I will do punishments against all the gods of Egypt.
I am the Lord.

And the blood shall be
to you for a sign on the houses where you are, and
I will see the blood, and I will have mercy on you,
and the plague will not be on you to destroy you when I slay
in the land of Egypt.

And this day shall be
to you for a memorial, and you shall keep it a feast to the Lord throughout your generations,
as an eternal statute, you shall keep it as a feast.

Seven days
shall you eat unleavened bread, but before the first day you shall remove
leaven from your houses. Because anyone who eats leavened |bread| from
the first day until the seventh day, that soul will be cut off
from Israel.

And there shall be for you a holy convocation on the first day
and a holy convocation on the seventh day.
No work shall be done on them. Just what is eaten by every man: that
alone shall be done for you.

And you shall observe the unleavened
bread, because in this very day I have brought your hosts
out from the land of Egypt. And you shall observe this day
throughout your generations as an eternal statute.

In the first
month, on the fourteenth day of the month, in the evening,
you shall eat unleavened bread, until the twenty-first day of the month,
in the evening.

Seven days leaven shall not be found in your
houses, because anyone who eats that which is leavened, that soul shall be cut off
from the congregation of Israel, both a stranger and a native of that land.

You shall eat nothing leavened. In all your dwellings
you shall eat unleavened bread.’

And Moses called for all the elders
of Israel, and said to them, ‘Pull out and take yourself
a sheep according to your families, and slay the Passover sacrifice.

And you shall take an aspergillum bunch and dip it in the blood that is in the vessel,
and touch the lintel and the two side posts
with some of the blood that is in the vessel. And you shall not go out at the door
of the house until the morning.

For the command of the Lord will pass through to slay
Egypt, and it shall see the blood on the lintel,
and on the two side posts, and
the Lord will have mercy on the door, and will not allow the
destroyer to come in to your houses to slay.

And
you shall observe this word for a statute to you and to your children
forever.

And it shall be, when you come to the land
which the Lord will give you as he has spoken, that you shall keep
this service.

And it shall be, that
your sons will say to you, “What is this service for you?”

And you shall say, “It is the sacrifice of the offering of the Passover
to the Lord who had mercy on the houses of the children of Israel
in Egypt, when he slew Egypt, and
saved our houses.”’ And the people bowed down and worshiped.

And the children of Israel went away and did as the Lord had commanded
Moses and Aaron. They did so.

And
it was at midnight, and the Lord slew all the firstborn in the land
of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh that sat on his throne
to the firstborn of the captive that was in the prison,
and all the firstborn of the livestock.

And Pharaoh rose up
in the night, he, and all his servants, and all the Egyptians, and there was a great
cry in Egypt, because there was not a house where there was not one
dead.

And Pharaoh called for Moses and Aaron
by night, and said, ‘Rise up, and go out from among my people,
both you and the children of Israel. And go, serve the Lord,
as you have said.

Take your sheep also,
your cattle, as you have said, and go and bless
me as well.’

And the people of Egypt became forceful on the people
to hurry to drive them out from the land, because they said,
‘We are all dead.’

And the people lifted and placed
their dough on their shoulders before
it leavened, their leavening vessels being
bound up in their bedsheets.

And the children of Israel
did according to the word of Moses, and they borrowed
from the Egyptians vessels of silver and vessels of gold and clothing.

And the Lord gave the people’s favour
in the eyes of the people of Egypt, so that they lent
to them. And they plundered Egypt.

And
the children of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth.
The young men, besides children: six times a hundred thousand on foot.

And
also a wild multitude went up with them, and sheep, and cattle,
a very strong livestock.

And they baked
unleavened dough which they brought out of Egypt: cakes of unleavened bread, because it was not leavened,
because they were driven out of Egypt and could not delay, and
they also had not prepared provisions for themselves.

And the stay
of the children of Israel that they stayed in Egypt, was four hundred years and
thirty years.

And it was in the course of the four hundred and thirty
years, and it was on the very same day that all
the hosts of the Lord went out from the land of Egypt.

It is a night
to be observed for the Lord for bringing them out from the land of Egypt. This is this night
to be observed for the Lord by all the children of Israel throughout their generations,
for taking them out even from this exile.

And the Lord said
to Moses and Aaron, ‘This is the statute of the
Passover: no foreigner shall eat of it.

And every man’s servant
that is bought for silver, if you have circumcised him, then
he shall eat thereof.
A settler and an hired servant shall not eat thereof.

It shall be eaten in one house, you shall not bring out any of the flesh
outside of the house, and you shall not break a bone of it.

All
the congregation of Israel shall do it.

And if
a stranger shall live with you, and shall want to do the Passover sacrifice to the Lord,
it is needed to let him be circumcised, every male, and then
he may come near to do it, and he shall be as one of the native of the land. But no
uncircumcised person shall eat of it.

One teaching shall be to the native,
and to the stranger who lives among you.’

And all the children of Israel did as the Lord commanded
Moses and Aaron, so did they.

And it was
the very same day: the Lord brought out the children
of Israel from the land of Egypt with their hosts.

app.note: A name of a meat dish; cf. Mam.Kipch. jaḫny ‘étuvée de viande’ (A. Zajączkowski 1958: 23).
K: ‘poor’; a scribal error, cf. Heb. וּבְאֶזְרַח ‘or a native’; cf. Exo 12:48, Exo 12:49, Lev 16:29, and Lev 17:15.
K: ‘would’; a scribal error, cf. Heb. יִתֵּן ‘will give’.
K: ‘poor’; a scribal error, cf. Heb. כְּאֶזְרַח ‘as a native’; cf. also Exo 12:19, Exo 12:49, Lev 16:29, and Lev 17:15.
K: ‘poor’; a scribal error, cf. Heb. לָֽאֶזְרָח ‘to a native’; cf. also Exo 12:19, Exo 12:48, Lev 16:29, and Lev 17:15.
